issue.title: Don't aggregate play-microbenchmark

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body: `play-microbenchmark` isn't meant to be published since it's not a publicly supported module and is only used internally by Play Framework for testing. It also need not be included in the whitesource check for this reason.

body: I also wanted to make sure the whitesource task didn't get run for microbenchmarks, since it's not something we actually distribute. It causes trouble because JMH is flagged as "GPLv2" for the license, even though technically it's GPL with classpath exception. Either way I think it's best not to report on libraries/licenses that have no effect on the end product.

OK @gmethvin thanks for explaining. I would like the microbenchmarks to be part of the main project so that we can ensure they don't rot. I'll try to figure out a way that does this and still works with whitesource.
I think it would be enough to have `.disablePlugins(PlayWhitesourcePlugin)` in microbenchmarks project.

issue.title: Avoid publishing microbenchmarks and integration tests artifacts

milestone.title: Play 2.8.0-M1
milestone.description:
First Play milestone release.

Highlights are:
* using Akka 2.6.0-M2, and
* cross-building to Scala 2.13.0-RC2

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Microbenchmarks weren't being published anymore, but they weren't also
being aggregated. This aggregates the project again but configures it not to release artifacts.

Integration tests on the other side are still being published, but this
is not intentional since this is an internal artifact used only to test
Play itself.

Fixes #7743.
